dt.t: the legal authorities helped by the {wi}opportune{/wi} use of their powers of arrest

et: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}opportun,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}opportūnus{/it} "favoring one's needs, serviceable, convenient," probably originally, "blowing in the direction of a harbor (of a wind)," from {it}ob-{/it} {et_link|ob-|ob-} + {it}portu-,{/it} stem of {it}portus{/it} "harbor, {et_link|port:1|port:1}" + {it}-nus,{/it} adjective suffix (vowel length perhaps after the ablative {it}portū{/it})
The name of a god of harbors, {it}Portūnus,{/it} appears to be a secondary formation by analogy with {it}Neptūnus{/it} "Neptune."
shortdef: suitable or convenient for a particular occurrence
